analysis: The documents primarily concern actions taken during World War II and its immediate aftermath. A recurring theme involves the federal government, particularly the War Department and the Navy Department, taking control of private companies and facilities to ensure the continued production of war materials and the efficient operation of essential services. Several orders address labor disputes and the need to maintain production levels in the face of these disputes. Some orders also deal with the transfer of resources and facilities from military to civilian control as the war winds down. One order concerns the sale of property held by the Attorney General. Overall, the documents reflect the broad mobilization of resources and the expansion of federal power during wartime, as well as the subsequent transition to a peacetime economy.
title: Federal Management of Wartime Production and Transition
